questions.text: A 72-year-old epileptic patient on Phenobarbitone took 10 tablets in the morning. He was drowsy and lethargic when bought to the emergency ward. The elimination of drugs can be enhanced by the following method:

options.label: C
options.text: By giving flumazenil which increases drug metabolism

options.label: D
options.text: By displacing the drug by inducing jaundice

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alkalinization of the urine

Highyeild:

Excretion of barbiturates can be increased by alkalinization of urine Phenobarbital is excreted unchanged in the urine to a certain extent (20–30% in humans), and its elimination rate can be increased significantly by alkalinization of the urine. This is partly due to increased ionization at alkaline pH since phenobarbital is a weak acid with a pKa of 7.4. Hence alkalinization of urine can increase the excretion of barbiturates.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Acidification of urine will increase the toxicity as phenobarbitone is a weakly acidic drug. Option: C. Flumazenil is antagonist of benzodiazepines, phenobarbitone is barbiturate Option: D. This is not useful.

questions.text: Barbiturates are useful in neonatal jaundice and contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria. The reason for this is?

options.label: D
options.text: Barbiturates increase the excretion of bilirubin in urine

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Barbiturates are enzyme inducers

Highyeild:

They increase the synthesis of Porphyrins by inducing the enzyme delta ALA-synthase (the rate-limiting enzyme in porphyrin synthesis) Thus, the effect of barbiturates on ALA synthetase can cause dangerous disease exacerbations in persons with intermittent porphyria. They are also used in Hyperbilirubinemia and kernicterus in neonates as barbiturates are enzyme inducers and increase glucuronyl transferase activity.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Barbiturates are enzyme inhibitors Option: B . Barbiturates displaces bilirubin Option: D . Barbiturates increase the excretion of bilirubin in urine

questions.text: A patient with a history of drug addiction had anxiety for the last three months. She was an active CEO of a company and needed to be alert in her work. Which of the following best suits her anxiety?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Buspirone

Highyeild:

BUSPIRONE Relieves anxiety without causing marked sedative, hypnotic, or euphoric effects. Acts as a partial agonist at brain 5-ht1a receptors with less addiction liability No rebound anxiety or withdrawal signs on abrupt discontinuance. The anxiolytic effects of buspirone may take more than a week to become established The major metabolite is 1-(2-pyrimidyl)-piperazine (1-pp), which has alpha-2-adrenoceptor-blocking actions little or no sedative effect & lacks the muscle relaxant & anticonvulsant properties of the benzodiazepines

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Topiramate Topiramate is used off-label for the treatment of Chronic alcoholism. It is a weak carbonic anhydrase inhibitor with broad-spectrum anticonvulsant activity in maximal electroshock, PTZ-induced clonic seizures, and the kindling model.

It helps decrease the nerve cells' abnormal and excessive activity and calms the brain. Option: D. Vigabatrin is a medication used to treat epilepsy. questions.text: The most common adverse effect of methyldopa is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sedation Sedation is typically used for common diagnostic tests that require prolonged immobilization, such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computed axial tomography (CAT) scanning. Some cases requiring sedation may also necessitate using analgesics to decrease pain associated with a procedure or test.

Highyeild:

Methyl- Dopa Adverse effects of methyldopa include sedation, lethargy, cognitive impairment, dry mouth, etc. Postural hypotension is generally mild. Positive Coomb’s test occurs in 1/6 of patients, and few develop haemolytic anaemia. Fever, rash, hepatitis, ‘flu-like illness, thrombocytopenia, and rarely lupus syndrome occur. Rebound hypertension on sudden withdrawal of methyldopa is mild and less common.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Convulsions are Sudden, uncontrolled electrical disturbances in the brain that can cause changes in behaviour, movements, feelings, and consciousness. Option: C. Nausea is described as a queasy or uneasy stomach, with or without the feeling that you are about to vomit. It can be a symptom of various conditions, ranging from mild and temporary to chronic and severe. Option: D. Flu-like symptoms are a medical diagnosis of possible influenza or other illness causing common symptoms. These include fever, shivering, chills, malaise, dry cough, loss of appetite, body aches, and nausea, sneezing, typically in connection with a sudden onset of illness. In most cases, the symptoms are caused by cytokines released by immune system activation and are thus relatively non-specific.
